Anthony Fu

Idan Ram

Driver.js: Tours, Highlights, Contextual Help, and More â€” A no-dependency, vanilla JavaScript library for putting together on-page tours and contextual help systems. There are lots of examples to check out â€“ itâ€™s reallyÂ smooth.

Kamran Ahmed

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Pines: A Library of UI Components for Alpine.js and TailwindÂ Projects â€” Includes sliders, tooltips, accordions, modals, and others. The CSS-only components are usable in any Tailwind project while the ones that require JS are designed for use withÂ Alpine.js.

devdojo

Standardized Audio Context: A Cross-Browser Web Audio APIÂ Wrapper â€” A side effect-free abstraction over a subset of the Web Audio API that works reliably across all mainstreamÂ browsers.

Christoph Guttandin

React Content Font: Create Custom Google Fonts from PageÂ Content â€” Fonts covering certain alphabets and languages can be particularly big (e.g. Noto Sans Japanese is almost 6 megabytes). What if you could request a font from Google Fonts containing only the characters youÂ need?

Adam Butterfield

Free Faces: A Curated Collection of Free Typefaces â€” The links are to a number of different font repositories around the web, so be sure to check each fontâ€™s usage license to ensure theyâ€™re webÂ friendly.

items.title: A is for aspect-ratio, B is for border..
items.content:
#â€‹601 â€” July 12, 2023 | Read on the web

Exploring Modern Alternatives to vh/vw Units â€” Ahmad brings us up to speed on the new(ish) small, large, and dynamic viewport units in CSS (e.g. svh, lvh, and dvh) and how they work across various mobile browsers. As ever, there are plenty of visuals to convey the points being made. Getting mobile page height right has long been tricky, but these new units make things more manageable and browser support is good too, which makes a niceÂ change.

Ahmad Shadeed

<The Case Against Self-Closing Tags in HTML /> â€” /> is sometimes ignored, and sometimes it isnâ€™tâ€¦ should we still be writing this? Should Prettier still be enforcing this? Does it matter? Jake shares his stance on a technique whose origin goes back more than 20Â years.

Jake Archibald

SDKs to Build Quality Product Onboarding â€” Dopt gives developers a component library and SDKs to build product onboarding and education in minutes. A visual builder lets the team map out flows; SDKs & APIs make it easy to develop them. Use Doptâ€™s prebuilt components or build withÂ yourÂ own.

Dopt sponsor

â–¶Â Â Modern CSS Layout is Awesome â€” A ~45-minute talk that will tell you what you need to know about modern approaches to CSS layout, covering some of the new features at our disposal and how to useÂ them.

Michelle Barker

WCAG 2.2: Quick and Simplified â€” With a new version of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines on the cusp of becoming a standard, hereâ€™s a brief, simplified look at the nine newÂ requirements.

Mike Gower

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Chris Coyier thinks about how features from Sass have gradually ended up in CSSÂ proper. Thanks Sass andÂ SCSS.

  • Aaron Francis looks at how you can 'write' PHP on the frontend using Laravel Livewire.

  • Manueo MatuzoviÄ‡ is seeking submissions for this year's HTMHell AdventÂ Calendar.

  • Where you at? No, Kelly Rowland couldn't have used Excel's =HYPERLINK() function to message Nelly. Apparently.

  • GitHub has added support for managing projects via GitHub Projects to its CLI tool.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Coding Randomized 'Tears of the Kingdom' Zelda Patterns â€” The new Zelda game (which Iâ€™m really enjoying btw â€” but I have a Nintendo newsletter for that) uses repeated, geometric patterns to build a cohesive aesthetic throughout the world. Paul looks at how to recreate this motif with code. A fun little SVG experiment, and a pen-plotting robot even gets involved.

Paul Hebert

Related: Daley Wilhelm looks at the UI considerations in the new Zelda.

Offset Parent and Stacking Context: Positioning Elements in All Three Dimensions â€” How you can use the offset parent and stacking context to position elements in all three dimensions, and how to debugÂ them.

Kilian Valkhof

How to Build a Web App in 60 Seconds Using AI â€” Dynaboard's low-code IDE offers 40+ built-in UI components & easy DB connections. Use AI to generate any SQL, JS &Â CSS.

Dynaboard sponsor

Permission â€” Itâ€™s generally accepted that our sites are crawled so people can find them via search, but are we ok with our sites being crawled to help train an LLM? In the evolving era of AI, Jeremy notes: â€œWe can rescind our invitation toÂ Googleâ€.

Jeremy Keith

Whatâ€™s the Best Font? See How You and Others Perceive Different Types â€” A neat interactive article that runs through the unique characteristics of a few fonts and shares how these differences areÂ perceived.

Kumar, Fowler, Shapiro (The Washington Post)

Shines, Perspective, and Rotations:Â FancyÂ CSSÂ 3D EffectsÂ forÂ Images
Temani Afif

All the Places You Can Use the prefers-color-scheme Media Query
Amit Merchant

Find Memory Leaks by Comparing Heap Snapshots in Chrome orÂ Edge
Patrick Brosset

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

SVG Hub: 70+ Custom-Color Elements Ready to Paste Into YourÂ Project â€” A unique set of graphics in SVG format consisting of squiggles, scribbles, and other unusual shapes â€” and you can live-edit the colors on the page to test out variousÂ palettes.

Daniel Cranney

ğŸ’¡Â Lucide is also cool if you want something more icon oriented.

Feature Flags That Work the Way You Code â€” DevCycleâ€™s feature flags integrate seamlessly with your workflow so you can ship faster using tools you alreadyÂ love.

DevCycle sponsor

Tailkits: A Directory of Tailwind CSS Templates, Components, andÂ More â€” Currently includes more than 250 products, and you can easily filter by free or paid and select by category (dashboards, landing pages, e-commerce, portfolios, etc).

Tailkits

Prettier 3.0 Released â€” The latest version of the popular code formatter (which isnâ€™t just for JavaScript, it tackles CSS, JSX, Markdown, and numerous templating formats too) isÂ here.

Sosuke Suzuki

Proportio: An Interactive Tool to Create Proportional Scales â€” Similar to other type scale tools, but this one is much more complete, allowing you to create proportional scales for type, shapes, components, and even containers. Lots to fiddle around withÂ here!

nate baldwin

MathLive: A Web Component for Math Input â€” A web component that provides an interface for editing formulas. It supports hundreds of LaTeX commands and uses LaTeX-style typesetting to keep things looking slick. GitHubÂ repo.

Arno Gourdol

svgps.app: Converts Your Icons into a Single JSON File â€” Converts icon packs into a JSON file that can be used in your app via child libraries for React, React Native, Preact, Vue andÂ Svelte.
Aykut KardaÅŸ

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ–ï¸ ...and finally

comiCSS: The ABCs of CSS â€” Each letter of the alphabet here is drawn with CSS and showcases one CSS property/value - like A for aspect-ratio. Thereâ€™s a live demo version hereÂ too.

Alvaro Montoro

items.content:
#â€‹600 â€” July 5, 2023 | Read on the web

A Deep Dive Into SVG Paths â€” This is a very well presented interactive guide to understanding SVG paths and path commands, covering cursors, lines, bÃ©zier curves, andÂ more. The inline comments are a neat feature offering extra context, and the creator is looking to release a more complete Interactive SVG Animations course later thisÂ year.

Nanda Syahrasyad

ğŸ’¡ In our Code and Tools section (below) we also link to SvgPathEditor, a handy minimal in-browser SVG path editor.

New Course: The Hard Parts of UI Development â€” Develop an under-the-hood knowledge of UI development by learning techniques such as data binding, UI composition, templating, virtual DOM and its reconciliation, and hooks, all fromÂ scratch!

Frontend Masters sponsor

Useful DevTools Tips and Tricks â€” Having worked on the developer tools in both Firefox and Edge, Patrick knows his stuff (he's shared over 100 tips on his tips site). In this post, he shares his topÂ 15, including disabling event listeners, copying element styles, visualising a page in 3D, and even changing the language of DevTools itself.

Patrick Brosset (Microsoft)

In Defence of DOMContentLoaded â€” A solid explainer on measuring browser events and the use cases for DOMContentLoaded (and its related events) in particular. "The DOMContentLoaded event fires once all of your deferred JavaScript has finishedÂ running."

Harry Roberts

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Version 115 of Firefox is out now adding hardware video decoding for Intel GPUs onÂ Linux.

  • Rachel Andrew's is back with her monthly round-up of what's new on the web platform (in June 2023, in thisÂ case).

  • Here are the release notes for Safari Technology Preview 173, which adds a new feature flags section, JPEG XL support, a new responsive design mode, and more.

  • In an effort to 'prevent fraud' the French government wants to inject state-operated domain blocking lists directly into browsers. ğŸ¤”

  • Ethernet is 50 years young. Here's why it has endured as the ubiquitous data framing protocol for half a century.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

What Does the decoding Attribute on Images Do? â€” An in-depth look at what the decoding attribute sets out to do, the nuance behind it, how it may have some performance gains in certain circumstances, and whether to consider it as part of your overall image renderingÂ strategy.

Barry Pollard

An Introduction to the View Transitions API â€” The experimental View Transitions API offers an easier way to animate between DOM states and even between page loads. Hereâ€™s a look at how to use this progressiveÂ enhancement.

Craig Buckler

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

â–¶Â Â State of the CSS Community â€” A talk from the recent CSS Day event in Amsterdam, highlighting the current excitement around CSS and the slew of new features that weâ€™ve seen come to the web platform over the past fewÂ years.

Una Kravets

First-Person Scrollers â€” Thereâ€™s something of a parallel between videogames and browser engines when it comes to them both having to maintain a solid, smooth frame rate. Eric notes how the evolution of web technologies and fresh new ideas, has to be balanced with meeting performance and rendering considerations. (I also just like the Halo-inspired UIÂ here.)

Eric Meyer

â–¶Â Â The Trick to Smoothly Animating Shadows in CSS â€” Animating a shadow can often be tricky as itâ€™s heavy on performance, but it can be important for maintaining a realistic sense of depth. Kevin shares a solution in just fiveÂ minutes.

Kevin Powell

"I Made 7 Predictions for the Web for the Next 5 Years" â€” A mixed bag of hits and misses here, but always fun to check in on some priorÂ predictions.

Fagner Brack

How to Use CSS background-size and background-position
Ralph Mason

Creating SVG Animations with Tailwind CSS
Mbaziira Ronald

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

SvgPathEditor: Edit and Save SVG Path Data â€” Lets you adjust all sorts of configuration and path settings while interactively adjusting the path via nodes in theÂ browser. Could be handy for creating adhoc bits of SVG.

Yann Armelin

Hurl 4.0.0: Powerful CLI HTTP Request Scripting â€” A powerful command line tool that runs HTTP requests written (scripted, really) in a plain text format. It can also be used to test HTTP responses and you can use variables to carry over elements of a response into a fresh request. It just hit versionÂ 4.0.

Orange

Minimal CLS Font Adjustment: A Tool to Automatically Match the Fallback Font for Improving CLS â€” By now youâ€™ve likely heard of 'cumulative layout shift' (a.k.a. CLS) and all its drawbacks. This tool aims to help you find matching fallback fonts to minimize the issue. It uses the size-adjust CSS descriptor for the @font-face at rule. (Note: Not supported in SafariÂ yet.)

Malte Ubl

Automize: The Missing Chrome DevTools Element Selector â€” Claims to offer a â€˜more intuitiveâ€™ GUI inside your devtools to make it easier to target deeply-nested elements, and works with test frameworks like Puppeteer, Playwright, Cypress, andÂ Selenium.

Automize

Zero-Runtime CSS with Vanilla Extract â€” Vanilla Extract is an alternative to CSS-in-JS (if that's your bag) that allows writing zero-runtimeÂ CSS in TypeScript. "Basically, itâ€™s â€œCSS Modules-in-TypeScriptâ€ but with scoped CSS Variables + heaps more."

Leonardo Maldonado

Creating a Ferris Wheel with Just CSS â€” Fancy a trip to the fair without even having to stand up? This is a neat, animated demo made using onlyÂ CSS. (Take care: it seems quite resource intensive.)
